s.text: But all were poor substitutes for true love and didn't vanquish his feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
But all were poor substitutes for true love and didn't vanquish his feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
Arianna Huffington is touting Levin on the air, and his book is stacked high by the register at my local Borders.

Basic premises: Clinton's reckless, repeated adultery weakens essential moral codes; his betrayal of vows and his lies undermine public trust; his use of legal chicanery to duck ethical responsibility is cowardly and grotesque; the public's silence in the face of this is a capitulation, "moral disarmament"; and America, which has always believed that politicians' moral behavior matters, must start judging Clinton's character.
Clinton deserves sympathy and compassion, not vitriol, because he exercises no control over his compulsive sexual behavior.
Clinton deserves sympathy and compassion, not vitriol, because he exercises no control over his compulsive sexual behavior.
Clinton deserves sympathy and compassion, not vitriol, because he exercises no control over his compulsive sexual behavior.

Like television, the book is a cool medium; Bennett's anger is convincing because he holds it in check.

"The more I thought about it," writes Levin, "the more I realized that Clinton had about as much chance of leaving her alone as a cocaine addict has of passing up a line."
"The more I thought about it," writes Levin, "the more I realized that Clinton had about as much chance of leaving her alone as a cocaine addict has of passing up a line."
Never mind that it's even more badly edited than High Crimes . Never mind that this flimflam is padded to book length with 100 pages of irrelevant stories about other addicts.
